description: Triggers when a page loads or is viewed, allowing you to execute tags based on page-specific conditions like URL patterns, referrer sources, or user characteristics.

when_to_use: Track page visits and implement page-specific analytics
Execute tags based on URL patterns or specific pages
Implement campaign attribution based on landing pages
Set up conversion tracking for specific pages
common_use_cases: Homepage tracking with specific analytics parameters
Product page view tracking with product-specific data
best_practices: Always include URL-based conditions to control trigger firing
Use 'equals' for exact page matches, 'contains' for page categories
Consider performance impact - avoid overly complex conditions
Test conditions thoroughly before publishing triggers
Use descriptive trigger names that indicate the page or purpose

create_trigger.description: Create a new page view trigger using this template

app_id.description: UUID of your Piwik PRO app

trigger_type.description: Must be 'page_view' for page view triggers

conditions.description: Array of condition objects that determine when the trigger fires

relationships.description: Can include tags to associate with this trigger

update_trigger.description: Update existing page view trigger - only editable fields will be processed

app_id.description: UUID of your Piwik PRO app

trigger_id.description: UUID of the trigger to update

attributes.description: Trigger attributes to update (non-editable fields will be filtered out)

relationships.description: Updated tag relationships (use '__unchanged__' to keep existing)

name.description: Human-readable trigger name that describes its purpose
name.recommendation: Use descriptive names that clearly indicate the page or purpose being tracked

trigger_type.edit_note: ⚠️ Cannot be changed after trigger creation

conditions.description: Array of condition objects that define when the trigger should fire

condition_id.description: Unique identifier for this condition (generate a new UUID)

variable_id.description: UUID of the variable to check (e.g., Page URL, Page Path, Referrer)

common_variables.page_url: Full page URL including domain and parameters
common_variables.referrer: Source URL that led to this page

value.description: Value to compare against (can be null for is_set/is_not_set conditions)

options.description: Additional options for the condition (usually empty for page view triggers)

conditions.recommendation: Include at least one URL-based condition to control when the trigger fires

url_pattern_match.description: Match pages that contain specific patterns

url_starts_with.description: Match pages that start with specific patterns

page_title_tracking.description: Track based on page title content

homepage_tracking.description: Track all visits to the homepage
homepage_tracking.use_case: Homepage analytics and conversion funnel entry point tracking

product_pages_tracking.use_case: Product analytics, inventory tracking, user interest analysis

thank_you_conversion.description: Track conversion on thank you/success pages
thank_you_conversion.use_case: Conversion tracking, goal completion, purchase confirmation

google_traffic_landing.description: Track Google organic traffic landing pages
google_traffic_landing.use_case: SEO performance tracking, organic traffic analysis

multi_condition_example.description: Track specific product page from specific traffic source

common_mistakes: Forgetting to generate unique UUIDs for condition_id fields
Using invalid variable_id references - ensure variables exist in your app
Creating overly broad conditions that fire on every page view
Using 'contains' when 'equals' would be more appropriate for exact matches
Not testing trigger conditions before associating with important tags
Using complex regex patterns that impact performance
Forgetting to include URL-based conditions, causing triggers to fire everywhere

possible_causes: Variable ID doesn't exist or is incorrect
Condition value doesn't match the actual page content
Condition type is incorrect for the data being compared
Trigger is not published or associated with tags
debugging_steps: Verify the variable exists using list_variables() tool
Check the actual page URL/title matches your condition value exactly
Test with simpler conditions first (e.g., contains vs equals)
Ensure trigger is published and associated with a tag

possible_causes: Conditions are too broad (using 'contains' when 'equals' would be better)
Missing additional conditions to narrow the scope
solutions: Add more specific conditions to narrow the trigger scope
Use 'equals' instead of 'contains' for exact matches
Test conditions on a staging environment first

tips: Page URLs include the full domain unless using Page Path variable
Page titles may include extra whitespace - use 'contains' instead of 'equals'
Referrer values may be empty for direct traffic

page_url.description: Complete URL including domain, path, and parameters

page_path.description: URL path without domain or parameters

referrer.description: URL of the page that linked to current page

getting_variable_ids.step_1: Use list_variables() to see all available variables in your app
getting_variable_ids.step_2: Find the variable you need (e.g., 'Page URL', 'Page Path')
getting_variable_ids.step_3: Copy the 'id' field from the variable object
getting_variable_ids.step_4: Use that UUID as the variable_id in your trigger conditions

best_practices: Limit the number of conditions per trigger (ideally 1-3)
Use specific conditions rather than broad patterns when possible
Avoid complex regex patterns that require heavy processing
Test trigger performance on high-traffic pages
Consider using page path instead of full URL when domain is constant
warning_signs: Triggers with 5+ conditions may impact page load time
Complex regex patterns can slow down trigger evaluation
Very broad conditions may cause excessive tag firing

create_trigger.description: Main function to create page view triggers using this template

list_triggers.description: View all existing triggers in your app
list_triggers.usage: list_triggers(app_id) - helpful to see existing page view triggers

get_trigger.usage: get_trigger(app_id, trigger_id) - study existing page view trigger setup

list_variables.description: Get all available variables for trigger conditions
list_variables.usage: list_variables(app_id) - find Page URL, Page Path, and other variable IDs

create_tag.description: Create tags that will be triggered by page view triggers
create_tag.usage: create_tag(..., triggers='trigger-uuid') - associate tags with page view triggers

step_1.purpose: Find the variable IDs for Page Path, Page URL, etc.

step_2.purpose: Create the trigger with appropriate conditions

step_3.purpose: Associate the trigger with a tag that will execute

step_4.purpose: Verify trigger works correctly before going live

field_mutability_guide.description: Understanding field editability after page view trigger creation

editable.description: ✅ Can be updated anytime after creation
editable.note: These fields can be safely modified through update_trigger operations

create-only.description: ⚠️ Set during creation, immutable after creation
create-only.note: These fields are ignored in update operations and cannot be changed once the trigger is created

read-only.note: These fields are managed by the API and automatically filtered out from update requests

update_workflow.description: Best practices for updating page view triggers
steps: 1. Use piwik_get_trigger() to see current field values and their mutability status
2. Only include editable fields in your update_trigger attributes object
3. API automatically filters out create-only and read-only fields
4. Focus on updating conditions to refine when the trigger fires
